meanings.def: to hit a door, etc. in order to attract attention
examples: He knocked three times and waited.
knock at/on something I knocked on the door and went straight in.
Somebody was knocking on the window.
Dobson walked straight into her office without knocking.
Someone knocked loudly at the door.
She knocked timidly on the study door and entered.

meanings.def: to hit something hard, often by accident
examples: knock something against/on something Be careful you don't knock your head on this low beam.
knock against/on something Her hand knocked against the glass.
knock something She dropped the pile of books when he accidentally knocked her shoulder.
The door's very low—mind you don't knock your head!
The stick knocked against the wall.

meanings.def: to hit something so that it moves or breaks
examples: knock something + adv./prep. He'd knocked over a glass of water.
I knocked the nail into the wall.
They had to knock the door down to get in.
He had knocked one of the pictures off the wall.
The boys were knocking (= kicking) a ball around in the back yard.
knock something (figurative) The criticism had knocked (= damaged) her self-esteem.
The boy was hit by a speeding car.
Someone had knocked a hole in the wall.
The baby was banging the table with his spoon.
The ship struck a rock.
In the darkness I bumped into a chair.
I braked too late, bashing into the car in front.
I accidentally knocked over his drink.
Mind you don't knock that glass over.
I accidentally knocked the vase off the table.

meanings.def: to put somebody/something into a particular state by hitting them/it
examples: knock somebody/something + adj. The blow knocked me flat.
He was knocked senseless by the blow.
knock somebody/something doing something She knocked my drink flying.
knock somebody/something + adv./prep. The two rooms had been knocked into one (= the wall between them had been knocked down).
The boy was hit by a speeding car.
Someone had knocked a hole in the wall.
The baby was banging the table with his spoon.
The ship struck a rock.
In the darkness I bumped into a chair.
I braked too late, bashing into the car in front.
The blow knocked him unconscious.
The explosion knocked him off his feet.
He was knocked flying as two policemen came crashing through the door.

meanings.def: to make a hole in something by hitting it hard
examples: They managed to knock a hole in the wall.

meanings.def: if your heart knocks, it beats hard; if your knees knock, they shake, for example from fear
examples: My heart was knocking wildly.

meanings.def: to make a regular sound of metal hitting metal, especially because there is something wrong
to criticize somebody/something, especially when it happens unfairly
examples: The newspapers are always knocking the England team.
It may sound pretty childish, but don't knock it until you've tried it.

meanings.def: to force people to stop arguing and behave in a sensible way
to hit somebody very hard several times and hurt them very much
examples: Get out or I’ll beat the living daylights out of you!

meanings.def: to hit somebody/something very hard
examples: He was a dirty player and loved to kick hell out of the opposition.

meanings.def: to surprise or impress somebody very much
to train somebody so that they do a particular job, task, etc. well
examples: It took him just two weeks to knock the new recruits into shape.

meanings.def: to make something more acceptable, organized or successful
examples: I've got all the information together but it still needs knocking into shape.
It shouldn’t take long to get the company back into shape.

meanings.def: to affect somebody very deeply
examples: The business over the lawsuit had really knocked her for six.

meanings.def: used to threaten somebody that you will hit them
to impress somebody very much
examples: You look fabulous—you'll knock ’em dead tonight.

meanings.def: to be very much better than somebody/something
examples: She knocks the rest of the cast into a cocked hat.

meanings.def: used to tell somebody to stop making a noise, annoying you, etc.
examples: Knock it off, kids—I’m trying to work.

meanings.def: to make somebody lose their position as somebody/something successful or admired
examples: A lot of teams are looking to knock us off our perch.

meanings.def: to stop something from happening; to stop doing something
examples: The recession knocked on the head any idea of expanding the company.
By eleven o’clock we were all tired so we knocked it on the head.

meanings.def: used when talking about your previous good luck or your hopes for the future, to avoid bringing bad luck
examples: I've been driving for over 20 years and never had an accident—knock on wood!

meanings.def: to surprise or shock somebody so much that they are unable to react immediately
to try and persuade somebody to stop behaving in a stupid way, sometimes using rough or violent methods
examples: Try and talk some sense into her before she makes the wrong decision.
Where would I be without you to knock some sense into my head?

meanings.def: to be very much better than somebody/something
examples: She knocks spots off all the other candidates.

meanings.def: to make somebody lose their confidence and enthusiasm
used to express surprise

meanings.def: the sound of somebody hitting a door, window, etc. with their hand or with something hard to attract attention
examples: knock on/at something There was a knock at the door.
I was startled by a loud knock on the car window.

meanings.def: a sharp hit from something hard
examples: He got a nasty knock on the head.
Knocks and scratches will lower the value of valuable furniture.

meanings.def: a bad experience that makes somebody/something less confident or successful
examples: Her confidence took a further knock when she lost her job.
The company has suffered two huge knocks of late.
Industry in the area has taken a knock with the closure of two factories.
Their pride took quite a knock when they lost 5–0.
